page.title: 06ABERLADY - THE VILLAGE
page.content:
Aberlady takes its name from the Gaelic "aber", at the mouth of, and "liobhaite", a smooth place, which is extremely descriptive of the bay.
There are two buildings of some significant size in the village itself and two others, one on the main eastern approach and the second on the main western approach to the village.
Aberlady Parish Church stands within its old kirkyard at the west end of the main street. The church is an attractive building of various periods. The square parapetted tower is of the 15th century, with a vaulted basement now used as the vestry, the main part of the building renewed in 1772 and later.
